storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want to receive real-time alerts for scheduling conflicts to take immediate action

functional.title: Verify real-time alert delivery via email when scheduling conflict is detected
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with valid credentials
User has email notification enabled in alert preferences
User email address is verified and active (scheduler@test.com)
Scheduling system is operational and connected to notification service
At least one existing appointment exists in the schedule

steps.action: Navigate to the scheduling dashboard and create a new appointment that overlaps with an existing appointment (e.g., both scheduled for 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM on the same date)
steps.expectedResult: System detects the scheduling conflict immediately and displays a conflict warning on the UI

steps.action: Click 'Confirm' button to proceed with the conflicting appointment creation
steps.expectedResult: System triggers the alert notification process and displays 'Alert sent' confirmation message

steps.action: Check the registered email inbox within 5 seconds of conflict creation
steps.expectedResult: Email alert is received with subject line 'Scheduling Conflict Detected' containing conflict details including appointment times, resources involved, and conflict ID

steps.action: Open the email and review the conflict details section
steps.expectedResult: Email displays complete conflict information: conflicting appointment IDs, time slots, resources, and suggested resolutions (reschedule, cancel, or reassign)

steps.action: Click the 'Resolve Conflict' link in the email
steps.expectedResult: Browser opens and navigates to the conflict resolution page with the specific conflict pre-loaded and highlighted

postconditions: Alert is logged in the notification history with timestamp and delivery status
Scheduling conflict remains unresolved and marked as 'Pending' in the system
User remains on the conflict resolution page ready to take action
Email delivery status is recorded as 'Delivered' in the notification service logs

functional.title: Verify real-time alert delivery via SMS when scheduling conflict is detected
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with valid credentials
User has SMS notification enabled in alert preferences
User mobile number is verified and active (+1-555-0123)
SMS gateway service is operational and configured
Notification service has sufficient SMS credits available

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict by double-booking a resource (e.g., Conference Room A for 10:00 AM - 11:00 AM)
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict and initiates alert notification process

steps.action: Check the registered mobile phone for SMS message within 5 seconds
steps.expectedResult: SMS alert is received with text: 'Scheduling Conflict: Conference Room A double-booked at 10:00 AM. Conflict ID: #12345. View details: [short link]'

steps.action: Click the short link provided in the SMS message
steps.expectedResult: Mobile browser opens and displays the conflict resolution page with conflict #12345 details loaded

steps.action: Review the conflict details on the mobile interface
steps.expectedResult: Page displays conflict information in mobile-optimized format with action buttons: 'Reschedule', 'Cancel Appointment', and 'Reassign Resource'

postconditions: SMS delivery is logged in notification history with timestamp and carrier response
Conflict remains active and visible in the scheduling dashboard
User session is maintained on mobile device for conflict resolution
SMS delivery cost is deducted from account credits

functional.title: Verify real-time in-app notification alert for scheduling conflict with acknowledgment capability
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler and actively viewing the scheduling dashboard
User has in-app notifications enabled in alert preferences
Browser notifications are allowed for the application domain
WebSocket connection is established between client and notification service
User has 'Manage Conflicts' permission enabled

steps.action: While on the scheduling dashboard, create a conflict by assigning the same staff member to two overlapping appointments (1:00 PM - 2:00 PM)
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict immediately and displays a red notification badge on the bell icon in the top-right corner

steps.action: Observe the in-app notification banner that appears at the top of the screen
steps.expectedResult: Banner displays with red background, alert icon, message 'Scheduling Conflict Detected: Staff member John Doe double-booked at 1:00 PM', and 'View Details' and 'Acknowledge' buttons

steps.action: Click the 'View Details' button on the notification banner
steps.expectedResult: Notification expands to show full conflict details including: Conflict ID, affected appointments, staff member name, time slots, and three suggested resolutions with action buttons

steps.action: Click the 'Acknowledge' button on the expanded notification
steps.expectedResult: Notification is marked as acknowledged, banner changes to yellow background with message 'Conflict acknowledged - awaiting resolution', and notification badge count decreases by 1

steps.action: Navigate to the 'Notifications History' page from the user menu
steps.expectedResult: Acknowledged conflict appears in the history list with status 'Acknowledged', timestamp, and 'Resolve' action button available

postconditions: Conflict acknowledgment is logged with user ID and timestamp in the database
Notification remains in history with 'Acknowledged' status until resolved
Conflict still appears in the active conflicts list on the dashboard
System tracks time-to-acknowledgment metric for reporting purposes

functional.title: Verify user can customize alert preferences for notification channels and conflict types
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with valid credentials
User has access to Settings or Preferences menu
Default alert preferences are set to email notifications only
User has verified email (scheduler@test.com) and mobile number (+1-555-0123)

steps.action: Navigate to Settings menu and click on 'Alert Preferences' option
steps.expectedResult: Alert Preferences page loads displaying current notification settings with sections for 'Notification Channels' and 'Conflict Types'

steps.action: In the 'Notification Channels' section, check the checkboxes for 'Email', 'SMS', and 'In-App Notifications'
steps.expectedResult: All three checkboxes are selected and highlighted in blue, indicating multiple channels are enabled

steps.action: In the 'Conflict Types' section, select 'Resource Conflicts', 'Staff Conflicts', and 'Time Conflicts' from the available options
steps.expectedResult: Selected conflict types are highlighted, and a preview message shows 'You will receive alerts for 3 conflict types via 3 channels'

steps.action: Set the 'Alert Frequency' dropdown to 'Immediate (Real-time)' and toggle 'Quiet Hours' to OFF
steps.expectedResult: Dropdown displays 'Immediate (Real-time)' and Quiet Hours toggle shows as disabled (gray)

steps.action: Click the 'Save Preferences' button at the bottom of the page
steps.expectedResult: Success message appears: 'Alert preferences saved successfully' in green banner, and page remains on preferences screen with updated settings displayed

steps.action: Create a test scheduling conflict (resource double-booking) to verify new preferences
steps.expectedResult: User receives alerts via all three channels (email, SMS, and in-app notification) within 5 seconds of conflict detection

postconditions: User preferences are saved in the database with timestamp of last update
All future alerts are sent according to the new preference settings
Preference change is logged in the audit trail with user ID and changes made
User remains logged in and on the Alert Preferences page

functional.title: Verify alert includes suggested resolutions and user can resolve conflict directly from alert
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with conflict resolution permissions
User has in-app notifications enabled
A scheduling conflict exists with ID #67890 (room double-booking)
System has calculated suggested resolutions for the conflict
User is viewing the scheduling dashboard

steps.action: Observe the in-app notification that appears for conflict #67890
steps.expectedResult: Notification displays with conflict details and a 'Suggested Resolutions' section showing 3 options: '1. Reschedule Appointment B to 3:00 PM', '2. Move to Conference Room B', '3. Cancel Appointment A'

steps.action: Click on the first suggested resolution: 'Reschedule Appointment B to 3:00 PM'
steps.expectedResult: A confirmation dialog appears with message: 'Reschedule Appointment B from 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM? This will resolve the conflict.' with 'Confirm' and 'Cancel' buttons

steps.action: Click the 'Confirm' button in the dialog
steps.expectedResult: System processes the resolution, displays loading spinner for 1-2 seconds, then shows success message: 'Conflict resolved successfully. Appointment B rescheduled to 3:00 PM.'

steps.action: Verify the notification banner updates after resolution
steps.expectedResult: Notification banner changes to green background with message 'Conflict #67890 resolved' and automatically dismisses after 3 seconds

steps.action: Check the scheduling dashboard calendar view
steps.expectedResult: Appointment B now appears at 3:00 PM slot with no conflict indicator, and the conflict warning icon is removed from the calendar

postconditions: Conflict #67890 is marked as 'Resolved' in the database with resolution method and timestamp
Appointment B is successfully rescheduled to 3:00 PM in the schedule
Resolution action is logged in audit trail with user ID and resolution details
Affected parties receive notification of the schedule change via their preferred channels

functional.title: Verify alert history logging and audit trail for all conflict notifications
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with admin privileges
Multiple scheduling conflicts have been created and resolved in the past 7 days
At least 10 alert notifications have been sent via various channels
User has access to 'Notification History' and 'Audit Logs' sections

steps.action: Navigate to the main menu and click on 'Notification History' option
steps.expectedResult: Notification History page loads displaying a table with columns: Date/Time, Conflict ID, Type, Channel, Status, Recipient, and Actions

steps.action: Review the list of notifications and verify the most recent entry
steps.expectedResult: Most recent notification shows: timestamp within last 24 hours, conflict ID, type (e.g., 'Resource Conflict'), channel (e.g., 'Email'), status ('Delivered'), and recipient email address

steps.action: Click on a specific notification entry to view detailed information
steps.expectedResult: Detail modal opens showing: full conflict details, notification content sent, delivery timestamp, acknowledgment status, resolution status, and user actions taken

steps.action: Apply filter to show only 'SMS' notifications from the 'Channel' dropdown
steps.expectedResult: Table updates to display only SMS notifications, and a filter tag 'Channel: SMS' appears above the table with count of filtered results

steps.action: Click the 'Export to CSV' button at the top-right of the page
steps.expectedResult: CSV file downloads with filename 'notification_history_[date].csv' containing all filtered notification records with complete details

steps.action: Navigate to 'Audit Logs' section from the admin menu
steps.expectedResult: Audit Logs page displays entries for all notification-related actions including: alert generation, delivery attempts, acknowledgments, and resolutions with user IDs and timestamps

postconditions: All notification history remains intact and accessible for future auditing
CSV export file is saved to user's downloads folder
User remains logged in and on the Audit Logs page
No data is modified during the history review process

negative.title: Verify system handles alert delivery failure when notification service is unavailable
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with email notifications enabled
Notification service is temporarily down or unreachable
Network connectivity between application and notification service is disrupted
User creates a scheduling conflict that should trigger an alert

steps.action: Simulate notification service failure by disconnecting the notification service endpoint
steps.expectedResult: Notification service returns 503 Service Unavailable or connection timeout error

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict by double-booking a resource
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict and attempts to send alert notification

steps.action: Observe the system behavior when notification delivery fails
steps.expectedResult: System displays error message: 'Alert notification could not be sent. The conflict has been logged and you will be notified when service is restored.' in yellow warning banner

steps.action: Check the notification queue or retry mechanism
steps.expectedResult: Failed notification is added to retry queue with status 'Pending Retry' and scheduled for automatic retry in 2 minutes

steps.action: Navigate to Notification History page
steps.expectedResult: Failed notification appears with status 'Failed - Service Unavailable' and retry count showing '0 of 3 attempts'

postconditions: Conflict is still logged in the system with 'Unresolved' status
Failed notification is queued for retry with exponential backoff strategy
System logs the failure with error details for troubleshooting
User is aware of the notification failure and can manually check for conflicts

negative.title: Verify system behavior when user has invalid or unverified email address for alert delivery
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler
User has email notification enabled in preferences
User's email address is invalid (e.g., 'invalid-email@') or unverified
Scheduling system is operational

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict to trigger an email alert
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict and attempts to send email notification

steps.action: Observe the notification delivery attempt
steps.expectedResult: Email service returns validation error: 'Invalid recipient email address' or 'Email address not verified'

steps.action: Check for error notification displayed to the user
steps.expectedResult: System displays error message: 'Alert could not be sent to invalid-email@. Please update your email address in Settings.' with a 'Go to Settings' button

steps.action: Review the notification history for this failed alert
steps.expectedResult: Notification entry shows status 'Failed - Invalid Email' with error details and no retry scheduled

steps.action: Verify that in-app notification is still delivered as fallback
steps.expectedResult: In-app notification appears with conflict details and additional message: 'Email delivery failed. Please verify your email address.'

postconditions: Failed email delivery is logged with specific error reason
User is prompted to update email address before receiving future email alerts
Conflict remains active and visible in the dashboard
System does not retry sending to invalid email address

negative.title: Verify system handles alert delivery when user has disabled all notification channels
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler
User has disabled all notification channels (Email: OFF, SMS: OFF, In-App: OFF) in alert preferences
User has saved these preferences successfully
Scheduling system is operational

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict by double-booking a staff member
steps.expectedResult: System detects the scheduling conflict successfully

steps.action: Observe whether any notification is sent or displayed
steps.expectedResult: No email, SMS, or in-app notification is sent to the user as per their preferences

steps.action: Check the notification history page
steps.expectedResult: Notification entry exists with status 'Not Sent - User Preferences' and note: 'All notification channels disabled by user'

steps.action: Verify that conflict is still logged and visible in the system
steps.expectedResult: Conflict appears in the scheduling dashboard with red warning icon and 'Unresolved' status

steps.action: Check if system displays a warning about disabled notifications
steps.expectedResult: Dashboard shows a persistent banner: 'You have disabled all alert notifications. You may miss important scheduling conflicts. Enable notifications in Settings.'

postconditions: Conflict is logged in the system with timestamp and details
No notifications are sent respecting user preferences
User is responsible for manually checking dashboard for conflicts
System logs that notification was suppressed due to user preferences

negative.title: Verify system behavior when alert delivery exceeds 5-second performance threshold
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with email notifications enabled
Notification service is experiencing high latency (simulated delay of 10 seconds)
System performance monitoring is active
Scheduling system is operational

steps.action: Simulate network latency by introducing 10-second delay in notification service response
steps.expectedResult: Notification service response time is artificially delayed to 10 seconds

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict to trigger an alert
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict and initiates alert notification process

steps.action: Monitor the time taken for alert delivery
steps.expectedResult: Alert delivery takes 10 seconds, exceeding the 5-second SLA threshold

steps.action: Check if system logs a performance warning
steps.expectedResult: System logs warning: 'Alert delivery SLA breach - Delivered in 10 seconds (threshold: 5 seconds)' with conflict ID and timestamp

steps.action: Verify that alert is still delivered despite delay
steps.expectedResult: Email alert is eventually delivered with all conflict details intact, but with delayed timestamp

steps.action: Check the notification history for SLA breach indicator
steps.expectedResult: Notification entry shows status 'Delivered - SLA Breach' with actual delivery time of 10 seconds highlighted in red

postconditions: Alert is delivered successfully despite exceeding performance threshold
SLA breach is logged for performance monitoring and reporting
System administrators are notified of performance degradation
User receives the alert but with delay beyond acceptable threshold

negative.title: Verify system handles unauthorized access attempt to alert preferences by non-Scheduler user
preconditions: User is logged in with 'Viewer' role (no Scheduler permissions)
User attempts to access Alert Preferences page directly via URL
Authorization middleware is active and enforcing role-based access
User does not have 'Manage Alert Preferences' permission

steps.action: Attempt to navigate to '/settings/alert-preferences' URL directly by typing in browser address bar
steps.expectedResult: System intercepts the request and checks user permissions

steps.action: Observe the system response to unauthorized access attempt
steps.expectedResult: System redirects to error page displaying '403 Forbidden - You do not have permission to access Alert Preferences' with a 'Return to Dashboard' button

steps.action: Attempt to access alert preferences via API endpoint POST /api/user/preferences/alerts with modified payload
steps.expectedResult: API returns 403 Forbidden response with JSON: {"error": "Insufficient permissions", "required_role": "Scheduler"}

steps.action: Check if unauthorized access attempt is logged in security audit trail
steps.expectedResult: Security log contains entry: 'Unauthorized access attempt to alert preferences by user ID [viewer_id] at [timestamp]'

postconditions: User remains on error page or is redirected to dashboard
No alert preferences are modified or accessed
Security incident is logged for review by administrators
User session remains active but access is denied

negative.title: Verify system handles malformed or missing conflict data when generating alert notification
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with notifications enabled
Database contains a conflict record with missing or corrupted data fields
Notification service is operational
System attempts to generate alert for the malformed conflict

steps.action: Trigger alert generation for a conflict record with missing appointment details (null appointment ID)
steps.expectedResult: System attempts to retrieve conflict details but encounters null or missing data

steps.action: Observe how system handles the missing data during alert generation
steps.expectedResult: System logs error: 'Unable to generate alert - Missing required conflict data: appointment_id' and does not send incomplete alert

steps.action: Check if user receives any notification about the error
steps.expectedResult: User receives generic in-app notification: 'A scheduling conflict was detected but details could not be retrieved. Please check the scheduling dashboard.' with 'View Dashboard' button

steps.action: Verify that the malformed conflict is flagged in the system
steps.expectedResult: Conflict appears in dashboard with special indicator 'Data Error' and status 'Requires Manual Review'

steps.action: Check notification history for the failed alert generation
steps.expectedResult: Notification history shows entry with status 'Failed - Data Error' and error message detailing missing fields

postconditions: No incomplete or malformed alert is sent to the user
Error is logged with details for technical team to investigate
Conflict is flagged for manual review and data correction
System continues to function normally for other conflicts

edgeCases.title: Verify alert delivery when multiple conflicts are detected simultaneously within same second
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with all notification channels enabled
System is configured to handle concurrent conflict detection
Notification service has sufficient capacity for burst notifications
Test environment allows creation of multiple simultaneous conflicts

steps.action: Create 5 different scheduling conflicts simultaneously using automated script or bulk import (e.g., 5 different resources double-booked at the same time)
steps.expectedResult: System detects all 5 conflicts within the same second and queues them for alert processing

steps.action: Monitor alert delivery for all 5 conflicts
steps.expectedResult: System sends 5 separate alert notifications, each within 5 seconds of detection, with unique conflict IDs and details

steps.action: Check in-app notification center for multiple alerts
steps.expectedResult: Notification bell icon shows badge with number '5', and notification panel displays all 5 conflicts in chronological order with timestamps

steps.action: Verify email inbox for multiple alert emails
steps.expectedResult: 5 separate emails are received, each with unique subject line including different conflict IDs, all delivered within 5-10 seconds

steps.action: Check notification history to verify all alerts were logged
steps.expectedResult: Notification history shows 5 entries with sequential timestamps (within same second), all with status 'Delivered', and correct conflict details

postconditions: All 5 conflicts are properly logged with unique IDs in the database
All 5 alerts are delivered successfully via all enabled channels
System performance remains stable with no degradation
No alerts are lost or duplicated during concurrent processing

edgeCases.title: Verify alert delivery when conflict is detected and immediately resolved before alert is sent
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with email notifications enabled
System has slight processing delay (1-2 seconds) between conflict detection and alert dispatch
User has quick access to conflict resolution interface
Notification service is operational

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict by double-booking a resource
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict and begins alert generation process

steps.action: Immediately resolve the conflict within 1 second by rescheduling one of the appointments before alert is sent
steps.expectedResult: Conflict is marked as 'Resolved' in the database before notification dispatch completes

steps.action: Check if alert is still sent or if it is cancelled
steps.expectedResult: System detects that conflict is already resolved and cancels the pending alert, or sends modified alert stating 'Conflict was detected and automatically resolved'

steps.action: Verify notification history for this conflict
steps.expectedResult: Notification history shows entry with status 'Cancelled - Conflict Resolved' or 'Sent - Already Resolved' with timestamp showing resolution occurred before dispatch

steps.action: Check that no unnecessary alert is delivered to user's email
steps.expectedResult: Either no email is sent, or email contains message: 'This conflict has been resolved. No action required.' with resolution details

postconditions: Conflict is marked as resolved in the system
User does not receive unnecessary alert for already-resolved conflict
System logs the race condition scenario for monitoring
Alert cancellation or modification is properly handled without errors

edgeCases.title: Verify alert delivery when user changes notification preferences during active alert processing
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with email notifications enabled
A scheduling conflict is created and alert processing is initiated
User has Settings page open in another browser tab
Alert is in queue but not yet dispatched (1-2 second processing window)

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict to trigger alert generation
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict and queues alert for email delivery

steps.action: Immediately switch to Settings tab and change notification preference from 'Email' to 'SMS only'
steps.expectedResult: Preference change is saved with timestamp in database

steps.action: Click 'Save Preferences' button before the queued alert is dispatched
steps.expectedResult: System saves new preferences: Email OFF, SMS ON

steps.action: Monitor which notification channel receives the alert
steps.expectedResult: System either: (a) sends alert via original channel (email) based on preferences at time of conflict detection, or (b) respects new preferences and sends via SMS instead

steps.action: Check notification history to see which preference was applied
steps.expectedResult: Notification history shows the channel used and includes note about preference change timing if applicable

postconditions: Alert is delivered via one of the channels (email or SMS) without duplication
System behavior is consistent and documented regarding preference change timing
No alerts are lost during preference update
Future alerts use the updated preferences

edgeCases.title: Verify alert delivery when user account is deactivated immediately after conflict detection
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with active account status
Administrator has access to deactivate user accounts
A scheduling conflict is created triggering alert generation
Alert is queued but not yet dispatched

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict as the Scheduler user
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict and queues alert notification for delivery

steps.action: Have administrator immediately deactivate the Scheduler user account before alert is dispatched
steps.expectedResult: User account status changes to 'Deactivated' in the database

steps.action: Monitor whether alert is still sent to the deactivated account
steps.expectedResult: System detects account is deactivated and either: (a) cancels the alert, or (b) sends alert to account administrator/supervisor instead

steps.action: Check notification history for handling of this scenario
steps.expectedResult: Notification history shows status 'Cancelled - Account Deactivated' or 'Redirected to Supervisor' with details of the action taken

steps.action: Verify that conflict remains logged and visible to authorized users
steps.expectedResult: Conflict appears in system dashboard accessible to administrators with note 'Created by deactivated user [username]'

postconditions: Alert is handled appropriately without causing system errors
Conflict data is preserved for audit and resolution purposes
Deactivated user does not receive notifications
Appropriate personnel are notified if conflict requires attention

edgeCases.title: Verify alert delivery with maximum character limits in conflict details and suggested resolutions
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with email and SMS notifications enabled
System allows creation of appointments with very long names and descriptions
Conflict involves appointments with maximum allowed character lengths (e.g., 500 characters for appointment name)
Notification templates have character limits for SMS (160 chars) and email subject (78 chars)

steps.action: Create two appointments with maximum length names (500 characters each) and descriptions (1000 characters each) that conflict
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict between appointments with very long names

steps.action: Observe the email alert that is generated
steps.expectedResult: Email subject line is truncated appropriately (e.g., 'Scheduling Conflict: [First 50 chars of appointment name]...'), and email body contains full conflict details without truncation

steps.action: Check the SMS alert that is sent
steps.expectedResult: SMS message is intelligently truncated to 160 characters with format: 'Conflict: [shortened appointment name]... at [time]. View: [short link]' ensuring critical information is preserved

steps.action: Review the in-app notification display
steps.expectedResult: In-app notification shows truncated preview with ellipsis, and 'View Full Details' button that expands to show complete conflict information

steps.action: Click through to view full conflict details from the alert
steps.expectedResult: Full conflict details page displays all information without truncation, including complete appointment names, descriptions, and suggested resolutions

postconditions: All alerts are delivered successfully despite long content
No data is lost, only intelligently truncated for display purposes
Users can access full details through provided links
System handles maximum character limits gracefully without errors

edgeCases.title: Verify alert delivery during system maintenance window or scheduled downtime
preconditions: System maintenance window is scheduled and active (e.g., 2:00 AM - 3:00 AM)
Notification service is in maintenance mode with limited functionality
User creates a scheduling conflict during the maintenance window
System has maintenance mode banner displayed

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict during the active maintenance window
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict despite being in maintenance mode

steps.action: Observe whether alert is sent immediately or queued
steps.expectedResult: System displays message: 'System is in maintenance mode. Alert notifications will be queued and sent when maintenance is complete.' and queues the alert

steps.action: Check notification queue status
steps.expectedResult: Alert appears in notification queue with status 'Queued - Maintenance Mode' and scheduled dispatch time showing 'After 3:00 AM'

steps.action: Wait for maintenance window to end (or simulate end of maintenance)
steps.expectedResult: System exits maintenance mode and begins processing queued notifications

steps.action: Verify that queued alert is delivered after maintenance completes
steps.expectedResult: Alert is delivered within 5 seconds of maintenance completion via all enabled channels, with note in alert: 'This alert was delayed due to system maintenance'

postconditions: All queued alerts are delivered successfully after maintenance
No alerts are lost during maintenance window
Conflicts remain logged and visible throughout maintenance
System resumes normal alert delivery after maintenance completion

accessibility.title: Verify complete keyboard navigation for alert notifications and conflict resolution workflow
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler using keyboard only (no mouse)
Screen is displaying the scheduling dashboard
A scheduling conflict exists triggering an in-app notification
Browser is set to show focus indicators clearly

steps.action: Press Tab key repeatedly to navigate through page elements until focus reaches the notification bell icon in the header
steps.expectedResult: Notification bell icon receives visible focus indicator (blue outline, 2px solid) and badge showing '1' is clearly visible

steps.action: Press Enter key to open the notification panel
steps.expectedResult: Notification panel opens, focus automatically moves to the first notification item, and panel is announced by screen reader as 'Notifications panel opened, 1 unread notification'

steps.action: Press Tab key to navigate through notification elements: conflict title, details, and action buttons
steps.expectedResult: Focus moves sequentially through: notification heading, conflict details text, 'View Details' button, 'Acknowledge' button, and 'Dismiss' button, each with visible focus indicator

steps.action: Press Enter key on the 'View Details' button
steps.expectedResult: Conflict details modal opens, focus moves to modal heading 'Conflict Details', and modal is announced as 'Dialog opened: Conflict Details'

steps.action: Press Tab to navigate through suggested resolutions and press Enter on first resolution option
steps.expectedResult: Focus moves through resolution options, confirmation dialog opens when Enter is pressed, and focus moves to 'Confirm' button in the dialog

steps.action: Press Escape key to close the confirmation dialog
steps.expectedResult: Dialog closes, focus returns to the resolution option that triggered the dialog, maintaining user's position in the workflow

steps.action: Press Escape key again to close the conflict details modal
steps.expectedResult: Modal closes, focus returns to the 'View Details' button in the notification panel that originally opened the modal

postconditions: All interactive elements are accessible via keyboard navigation
Focus order is logical and follows visual layout
Focus is never trapped in any component
User can complete entire conflict resolution workflow using keyboard only

accessibility.title: Verify screen reader announcements for real-time alert notifications and conflict details
preconditions: User is logged in as Scheduler with screen reader enabled (NVDA or JAWS)
Screen reader is configured to announce live regions and notifications
User is on the scheduling dashboard
System is ready to detect scheduling conflicts

steps.action: Create a scheduling conflict to trigger an in-app alert notification
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader immediately announces: 'Alert: Scheduling conflict detected. Conference Room A is double-booked at 2:00 PM. Press Alt+N to view notification.' using assertive ARIA live region

steps.action: Navigate to the notification bell icon using screen reader navigation commands
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader announces: 'Notifications button, 1 unread notification, collapsed' with clear indication of interactive element and state

steps.action: Activate the notification bell to open the notification panel
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader announces: 'Notifications panel, expanded, region. Heading level 2: Scheduling Conflict. 1 of 1 notifications. Conflict ID 12345.'

steps.action: Navigate through the conflict details in the notification
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader reads: 'Conflict details: Conference Room A is double-booked. Appointment A: 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM. Appointment B: 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM. Suggested resolutions: List with 3 items.'

steps.action: Navigate to and activate the 'View Details' button
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader announces: 'View Details button' when focused, then 'Dialog opened: Conflict Details' when activated, followed by reading the modal content

steps.action: Navigate through suggested resolutions in the modal
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader announces each resolution as: 'Option 1 of 3: Reschedule Appointment B to 3:00 PM, button' with clear numbering and action type

steps.action: Activate a resolution and listen to confirmation announcement
steps.expectedResult: Screen reader announces: 'Conflict resolved successfully. Appointment B has been rescheduled to 3:00 PM. Notification dismissed.' using polite ARIA live region

postconditions: All critical information is announced by screen reader
Announcements are clear, concise, and provide context
Live regions are used appropriately (assertive for urgent alerts, polite for confirmations)
User can understand and act on alerts using screen reader alone

accessibility.title: Verify ARIA labels, roles, and properties for alert notification components
preconditions: User is on the scheduling dashboard with browser developer tools open
Accessibility inspector or axe DevTools extension is active
A scheduling conflict notification is displayed
User has access to inspect HTML and ARIA attributes

steps.action: Inspect the notification bell icon element in the header
steps.expectedResult: Element has: role='button', aria-label='Notifications, 1 unread', aria-expanded='false', aria-haspopup='true', and aria-controls='notification-panel'

steps.action: Inspect the notification badge showing unread count
steps.expectedResult: Badge has: aria-label='1 unread notification' and is not just decorative, ensuring count is announced to screen readers

steps.action: Open notification panel and inspect the panel container
steps.expectedResult: Panel has: role='region', aria-label='Notifications', aria-live='polite', and aria-atomic='false' for dynamic content updates

steps.action: Inspect individual notification item for conflict alert
steps.expectedResult: Notification has: role='article', aria-labelledby='notification-title-12345', and contains proper heading structure (h2 for title, h3 for sections)

steps.action: Inspect the conflict details modal dialog
steps.expectedResult: Modal has: role='dialog', aria-modal='true', aria-labelledby='dialog-title', aria-describedby='dialog-description', and focus trap implemented

steps.action: Inspect suggested resolution buttons
steps.expectedResult: Each button has: descriptive aria-label like 'Reschedule Appointment B to 3:00 PM, option 1 of 3', and aria-pressed or aria-selected states where applicable

steps.action: Inspect the alert success/error messages after resolution
steps.expectedResult: Messages use: role='alert' or aria-live='assertive' for errors, aria-live='polite' for success, ensuring immediate announcement without user action

userStoryObject.description:
CONTEXT & BACKGROUND:
This story ensures that users are promptly informed of any scheduling conflicts, allowing for quick resolutions.

CURRENT STATE:
Currently, users are not notified until after a conflict has occurred, leading to delays in resolution.

DESIRED STATE:
The system should provide immediate alerts to users when conflicts are detected, enabling them to take corrective actions swiftly.

KEY FUNCTIONALITY:
 Send alerts via email, SMS, or in-app notifications.
 Include details of the conflict in the alert.
 Allow users to acknowledge or resolve conflicts directly from the alert.
 Log alert history for auditing.
 Provide options for users to customize alert preferences.

USER INTERACTION FLOW:
1. System detects a scheduling conflict.
2. System generates an alert notification.
3. User receives the alert via their preferred channel.
4. User reviews the conflict details.
5. User takes action to resolve the conflict.

TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS:
 Data source: Notification service.
 Validation rules: Ensure alerts are sent to the correct users.
 API endpoints: POST /api/notifications/send for alert dispatch.
 Security: Ensure user preferences are securely stored.
 Performance: Alerts sent within 5 seconds of conflict detection.

OUT OF SCOPE:
 Historical alert analysis.

SUCCESS METRICS:
 95% of alerts delivered within 5 seconds.
acceptanceCriteria: System sends alerts to users within 5 seconds of detecting a scheduling conflict.
Alerts include details of the conflict and suggested resolutions.
Users can customize their alert preferences.
